awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Competition and interactions among predators of bacteria in microbial loop dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University aims to study the ecological role of predatory bacteria, Bdellovibrio-like organisms (BALOs), in marine waters.  The project outcome can reveal interactions not only amongst the bacterial predators but also among the predators and their prey bacteria under various environmental factors. 

The scientific objectives of this study are to: investigate how viruses, Halobacteriovorax, and heterotrophic protists effect one another in decreasing bacterial abundance; quantify the relative proportion of all three mortality mechanisms on bacterial loss; determine environmental effects on predatory activities of protists, viruses, and Halobacteriovorax; and model population dynamics of predators and prey. The approach to accomplishing these objectives is to measure loss rates of a virus, heterotrophic protist, and a Halobacteriovorax on the mortality of bacteria in laboratory microcosms and field studies. The novelty and innovativeness of this approach is that while many of these components have been examined independently, this would be the first time that mortality is quantitatively partitioned for this complex system. The expected high-payoff from this innovative Early-Concept for Exploratory Research project is transformative results that dramatically increase understanding of tri-trophic planktonic interactions that significantly influence oceanic biogeochemical fluxes of carbon and nutrients through the microbial loop and reveal Halobacteriovorax as a major bacterial predator.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
When predators come to mind images conveyed typically include those of lions, tigers, sharks and other large animals. Less imagined are predatory organisms that are microscopic, so small that they can only be visualized with the aid of a microscope. Yet, microscopic predators, or micropredators, are common in the environment, including soil, water and man-made structures such as sewage treatment facilities. The roles of micropredators in the environment are of major significance. The cycling of carbon and other nutrients in the world’s oceans and seas and other marine bodies is largely due to predation, accompanied by lysis or disintegration of the prey bacteria by rupturing the outer cell membrane. Another major function of predators is to control the population of their prey. Organisms without natural predators may become overpopulated in an ecosystem and upset the natural balance of the overall population and biodiversity.  Micropredators are a key link in the mortality of their prey bacteria resulting in the cycling of nutrients and carbon in the ocean. Thus identifying and quantifying them and their roles, and factors that mediate their population dynamics, is crucial to understanding Earth’s carbon cycle and by extension, the impact of continued anthropogenic perturbation of CO2 levels. The most studied micropredators, and those deemed to be the most important, are protists and viruses. However, recent evidence suggests that another micropredator, a group of predatory bacteria known collectively as the Bdellovibrio and like-organisms (BALOs), may be as important as viruses and protists, yet their roles have not yet been widely accepted. It is necessary that this omission be rectified.

A major focus of this study was to better understand the roles of the various micropredators in the predation of bacteria and the cycling of nutrients. We were particularly interested in comparing the role of Halobacteriovorax, a type of BALOs, to that of the protists and viruses, and in further exploring if they are major predators of bacteria.  Questions which we posed to address the objectives in this study included the following: Which is the predominant micropredator? How do the various micropredators interact and compete for the available prey bacteria? Does the interactions between the various micropredators affect predation by each of them? What factors mediate the population dynamics of the micropredators? To answer these questions, we will observe how the native micropredators in environmental waters respond, as determined by changes in their populations’ abundances, in response to increases in populations of prey bacteria. We will show how the viruses, Halobacteriovorax, and protists alter the effectiveness of one another in decreasing bacterial abundance. To answer the question as to how the various micropredators respond to a sudden increase in a common prey bacterium, water. In the laboratory, over 10 million prey bacteria were inoculated into flasks containing 250 ml of water collected from the Apalachicola Bay in northwest Florida, USA. The highly turbid, prey infused water sample was then incubated at 25 C while being shaken. Every three hours for up to 7 days, samples were removed from the flasks, measured for turbidity reduction, an indication of killing of the prey, and preserved for subsequent analyzes for changes in the virus, Halobacteriovorax, and protist populations over the course of the time-series experiment. The observations from several experiments showed that typically the first micropredator to respond to the inoculum of the prey bacterium was the Halobacteriovorax. This early predation by the Halobacteriovorax reduced the prey population some, leaving less prey for the other micropredators and dampening their growth. Subsequently, protist predation became evident. It appears that the protist preyed not only on the prey bacterium, but also on the Halobacteriovorax and possibly the viruses. These speculations require further confirmation. The viruses typically did not show substantial predation activity until the last days of the experiment.

The experimental results showed that the Halobacteriovorax were the first responders, and the most aggressive micropredators early in the time-series experiments. This shows that the Halobacteriovorax, which had been downplayed previously, play a significant role in bacterial predation and the consequent cycling of nutrients in aquatic systems. These results call for a reversal in the failure to fully recognize the Halobacteriovorax as having important roles in the environment. For a full understanding of the global cycling of nutrients and its impact on greenhouse gases and climate change, it is important that all micropredators contributing to predation in aquatic environments be recognized and further studied. 

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2022
Modified by: Henry N Williams
